name: Sylvie Bernier
description: A diver from a young age, Sylvie Bernier joined the Canadian team in 1978 and won five national titles prior to her retirement in December 1984. She won her first major international medal, silver in the 3 metre springboard behind Jenny Donnet of Australia, at the 1982 Commonwealth Games, and followed it up with bronze medals in the same event at the Pan American Games, the FINA World Cup, and the Summer Universiade in 1983. She entered the 1984 Summer Olympics as a favorite, but was expected to be knocked off the podium by the American and Chinese competitors. She performed well in the qualifiers, placing third behind Li Yihua and Kelly McCormick, but pulled off a surprising victory by winning the final by just over three points ahead of McCormick. Bernier’s feat earned her induction into the Order of Canada (1985), Canada’s Sports Hall of Fame (1987), and the International Swimming Hall of Fame (1996), as well as the Bobbie Rosenfeld Award as Canadian Female Athlete of the Year in 1984. Following her retirement at the end of the year, she became involved in broadcasting and television and worked as a commentator for the 1988 and 1992 Summer Olympics. She also served as the Chef de Mission for Canada’s delegation to the 2008 Games, as well as Assistant Chef de Mission in 2006 and 2012. As of 2012, she remains Canada’s only Olympic diving champion.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 1983 Caracas DIV bronze: 3 m springboard) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–0–1 1983 Edmonton DIV bronze: 3 m springboard) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 1982 Brisbane DIV silver: 3 m springboard)

name: Dietmar Göhring
description: Dietmar Göhring was a backstroke swimmer who was eliminated in the semi-finals of the 100 metres and in the heats of the 200 metres at the 1980 Moskva Olympics. Also, with the East German 4x100 medley relay squad he finished an unfortunate fourth. In 1979 and 1980, Göhring won the East German national title in the 100 metres.

name: Mike Yonker
description: Mike Yonker rowed for the University of Washington and later represented the Lake Washington Rowing Club. Yonker won a gold medal at the 1959 Pan American Games in coxed fours. His Lake Washington RC four won the title at the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen (NAAO) meet in 1959-62, which qualified them for the 1959 Pan Ams and 1960 Olympics.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1959 Chicago ROW gold: coxed fours)

name: Mike Freeman
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Bob & Skeleton Championships (0–0–2 1968 St. Moritz bronze: Two-man and Four-man)

name: Jagjit Singh
description: One of fourteen Olympic hockey players produced by the village of Sansarpur (population 4,000), Jagjit Singh was educated at Lyallpur Khalsa College, Jalandhar and at Panjab University where he was a member of the hockey team that won the Inter-University hockey championship in 1960. After graduating he joined the Punjab Police where his performances in midfield brought him first to the attention of the selectors of the Punjab state team and then, in 1964, a call-up to the national team for their tour to New Zealand and Malaysia. Singh was only a fringe player at the 1964 Olympics and played in just two of India’s nine games as they won the gold medal but figured more prominently when they won the Asian Games in 1966. He toured extensively with the Indian team through the mid sixties playing in Europe (1965), Japan (1966), Sri Lanka and Afghanistan (1967), East Africa and Egypt (1968) and France (1968) and helped the team win the tournaments in Hamburg in 1965 and Madrid in 1967. He also participated in the pre-Olympic tournament in London in 1968. A first-choice for India at the start of the 1968 Games he lost his place after the opening game loss to New Zealand and that signaled the end of his career with the national team. At domestic level he played for Punjab Police until 1967 when he was promoted to deputy superintendent with the Border Security Forces. In tandem with his career with the Police and BSF teams he played eight years with the Punjab state team and was captain in 1968. A winner of the Arjuna Award, India’s premier sporting honour, in 1967 he had suffered ill health for many years before his death in 2010.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (1–0–0 1966 Bangkok HOC gold)

name: Pietro Leone
description: Pietro Leone won five Italian titles as a midfielder with US Pro Vercelli, in 1908-09 and 1911-13. In these years he played nine times for the Italian national team, including all the matches at the 1912 Stockholm Olympics. Leone coached in the 1930s but with little success.

name: Paulette Laurent
description: Personal Best: SP – 12.71 (1950).

name: Mario Quintero
description: Mario Quintero played basketball for Cuba at the 1948 and 1952 Olympics. He also competed at the 1946 Central American and Caribbean Games, won a bronze medal at that tournament in 1950, and competed at the first Pan American Games in 1951. Quintero later became much better known as a coach and referee, and in 1953 he was the first Cuban to receive international referee certification. He coached the Cuban women’s national team at the 1953 and 1956 World Championships, and the men’s team from 1959-68. He refereed in over 1,000 international games, including at the 1968, 1972, 1976, and 1980 Olympics, the 1974 and 1978 World Championships, at three Pan American Game, and four Central American and Caribbean Games.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (0–1–1 1946 Barranquilla BAS silver; 1950 Ciudad de Guatemala BAS bronze)

name: Leszek Lubicz-Nycz
description: Leszek Lubicz-Nycz won bronze in 1930 and 1934 at the unofficial World Championships with the team sabre. In 1931 and 1934 he was the Polish champion in individual sabre. After his active career he became a fencing and ski instructor at the Central Institute of Physical Education in Warszawa, where he also wrote a book about skiing. He also qualified as an international fencing judge. During World War I Lubicz-Nycz served in the Polish Legions. After 1918 he was a soldier in the Polish Army and was decorated for his participation in the war against the Bolsheviks. At the beginning of World War II, he fell in the first days of the German invasion of Poland in the Battle of Łomianki, near Warszawa, and was posthumously promoted to the rank of lieutenant-colonel. His brother Bronisław took part in the Warszawa uprising, but was arrested after World War II as an oppositionist.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (0–0–2 1930 Liège bronze: sabre team; 1934 Warszawa bronze: sabre team) Listed in Olympians Who Were Killed or Missing in Action or Died as a Result of War (†22 September 1939. He was killed in action in Buraków near Warsaw during the September Campaign.)

name: Arnold Martignoni
description: Arnold Martignoni was a goaltender who played for EHC St. Moritz in the Swiss National League A from 1921-31, although he sat out the 1929-30 season after an injury from being hit by a puck. With that team he won Swiss titles in 1922-23 and 1928. He played three games for Switzerland at the 1926 European Championships, helping them win the title that year. He was also on the Swiss team at the 1923 European Championships when they finished fifth. Martignoni worked as a tinsmith.
special_notes: Brother of Adolf Martignoni Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Ice Hockey Championships (1–1–0 1926 Davos gold; 1928 St. Moritz (Olympics) silver) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Ice Hockey Championships (0–0–1 1928 St. Moritz (Olympics) bronze)

name: Sheila Armstrong
description: Sheila Armstrong was from New Jersey and competed for Salle Santelli. She attended Cal Poly Ponoma. Armstrong placed second in foil at the 1975-76 US Championships. She competed at the 1975 Pan American Games, winning a bronze medal in team foil. In 1976 Armstrong was working as an executive secretary to support her training, but she later became an artist, opening Armstrong Studios.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 1975 Ciudad de México FEN bronze: foil team)

name: Marcel-Frédéric Lubin-Lebrère
description: Marcel-Frédéric Lubin-Lebrère played lock forward for France in rugby football at the 1924 Paris Olympics. He was capped 15 times for France, usually playing prop forward. Lubin-Lebrère played for US Montalbanaise early in his career and then was with Stade Toulousain from 1913-25, winning French titles with them in 1922, 1923, and 1924, after losing in the 1921 final. He later became a coach with Stade Toulousain in 1927-28. He was also a useful fencer, competing in regional competitions. Lubin-Lebrère was badly injured in World War I, losing an eye. He later became a municipal employee of Toulouse, working with brick materials and in their gardens. In 1920 Lubin-Lebrère was arrested in a pub in Dublin for singing La Marseillaise, against the wishes of the Irishmen present.

name: Ashok Kumar
special_notes: Son of Dhyan Chand Nephew of Roop Singh Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–3–0 1970 Bangkok HOC silver; 1974 Tehran HOC silver; 1978 Bangkok HOC silver)

name: Taisto Laitinen
description: Taisto Laitinen was a Finnish pole vaulter who represented FC Haka. Laitinen won the silver medal at the Nordic Championships in 1963 and at the Kaleva Games in both 1963 and 1964. At the 1964 Tokyo Olympics he finished in 14th place after clearing the qualifying height of 4.60 metres, but failing to clear 4.70 metres in the final. Personal Best: PV – 4.86 (1964).

name: Maksat Boburbekov
description: Maksat Boburbekov had the following finishes at major championships – 1999 World Championship: 63.0 kg. Freestyle (8th); 1994 World Championship: 57.0 kg. Freestyle (10th); 1997 World Championship: 63.0 kg. Freestyle (22nd); 1995 Asian Championship: 57.0 kg. Freestyle (3rd); 1997 Asian Championship: 63.0 kg. Freestyle (5th); 1994 Asian Games: 57.0 kg. Freestyle (2nd); 1998 Asian Games: 58.0 kg. Freestyle (5th).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–1–0 1994 Hiroshima WRE silver: freestyle bantamweight -57 kg)

name: Nijolė Sabaitė
description: Lithuanian Nijolė Sabaitė had a very brief international career. After winning the 800 bronze medal at the 1968 European Junior Championships, She was selected for the Soviet national team in 1970. She competed at the 1971 European Championships, but was eliminated in the semi-finals of the 800. In 1972 Sabaitė won an 800 silver at the Olympics and in 1973 won silver at the Universiade and bronze at the European Cup. She was the Soviet 800 champion in 1972-73 and was a five-time Lithuanian SSR champion. Sabaitė finished her sports career after graduating from the Vilnius Pedagogical Institute (now Lithuanian University of Educational Sciences) with a special education degree and later worked with disabled children at the Vilnius University Children’s Hospital and at various Vilnius disabled children homes. Personal Best: 800 – 1:58.65 (1972).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–1–0 1973 Moskva ATH silver: 800 m)

name: Louis Ségura
description: Held Spanish nationality at birth.

name: Stanisław Szozda
description: Stanisław Szozda is among the greatest ever Polish cyclists, winning two Olympic silver medals in the 1972 and 1976 team time trial, and five medals at the World Championships. In 1973 and 1975 he won gold medals at the Worlds in the team time trial, winning an individual silver in the amateur road race in 1973, and adding bronze medals in the team time trial in 1971 and 1977. He also won the 1974 Peace Race, finishing second in that event, then called the amateur Tour de France, in 1976, as well as helping Poland win the team classification in 1973. Szozda’s other major wins included the 1971 Tour of Poland, the 1973 Tour of Algeria, the 1973-74 Tour of Toledo, the 1974 Settimana Bergamasca, the 1976 Tour of Malopolska, and the 1977 Szlakiem Grodow Piastowskich. Szozda won five Polish national championships. His racing career ended after sustaining a spine injury at the 1978 Peace Race. After his competitive retirement, Szozda moved to the United States for a time where he worked as a trainer with Eddie Borysiewicz. He later returned to Poland where he was successful as a businessman. Szozda received the Order of Polonia Restituta.

name: Jin Gap-Yong
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (1–1–0 1994 Hiroshima BSB silver; 1998 Bangkok BSB gold)

name: Les Tipton
description: Les Tipton was NCAA javelin champion in 1964, competing for the University of Oregon. He also finished fifth in that event in 1962. He was fifth at the AAU Meet in 1969. Tipton competed at both the 1964 and 1972 Olympic Trials, finishing second in 1964 and fifth in 1968. Tipton graduated from Oregon with a degree in art and returned to the school to obtain a masters’ degree in art. He later became a college professor. Personal Best: JT – 80.42 (263-10) (1972).

name: Willi Fischer
description: Willi “de Ox” Fischer was a German super-heavyweight boxer who reached the quarter-finals at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. He then lost to the Bulgarian Svilen Rusinov by an 8-5 decision. Fischer won the International German Championships three years between 1996 and 1999. He was later twice suspended from competition sports due to doping irregularities and never really came back in the 2000s. He retired in 2009 without any more success. By profession, he became a self-employed fitness and personal trainer.

name: Betzabeth Argüello
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–1 2015 Toronto WRE bronze: freestyle featherweight -53 kg; 2019 Lima WRE silver: freestyle featherweight -53 kg) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (1–0–1 2014 Veracruz WRE bronze: freestyle featherweight -53 kg; 2018 Barranquilla WRE gold: freestyle featherweight -53 kg)

name: Noodang Pimpol
description: Noodang Phimphoo was Thailand’s leading femal 400 m runner from 1991 to 1995. She was a member of the team that won bronze in 4×400 m at the Asian Championships in 1991 and 1995 and the Asian Games 1994. Her best individual placing was 4th in the Asian Championship in 400 m 1995. After competing in the Olympics in 1992, she also ran the 400 m in the World Championship 1994. Personal Best: 400 – 52.60 (1993).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–0–1 1994 Hiroshima ATH bronze: 4×400 m relay)

name: Angelina Grün
description: German volleyball player Angelina Grün was born in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. She was considered one of the best female volleyball players of her time and was named Volleyball Player of the Year nine times. She later married her team-mate Stefan Hübner. At the 2000 Sydney Olympics, Grün placed sixth with the German squad and in 2004 placed ninth. In total, she won 297 international caps, and won a bronze medal at the 2003 European Championships, and silver in 2011. At club level, Grün played with VC Essen-Borbeck (1990-96), USC Münster (1996-2001), Edison Volley Modena, Italy (2001-03), Voppapedretti Bergamo, Italy (2003-08), VakıfBank Spor Kulübü İstanbul, Turkey (2008-09), Alemannia Aachen (2011), Dynamo Moskau, Russia (2011-12), Rabita Baku, Azerbaijan (2012-13), and finally, after giving birth to her first child, with SG Marmagen-Nettersheim (2014-16). Grün won numerous titles in her domestic career. She won the German Championship in 1997, German Cup in 2000, Italian Cup in 2002 and 2006, Italian Championship in 2004 and 2006, Russian Cup in 2011, and Azerbaijan Championship in 2013. She also won the CEV Cups in 2002 and 2004, and the European Champions League in 2005 and 2007. Due to injuries she sustained, Grün tried playing beach volleyball for one season in 2010.
special_notes: Wife of Stefan Hübner Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Volleyball Championships (0–1–1 2003 TUR bronze; 2011 ITA/SRB silver)

name: Jeremy Wotherspoon
description: Jeremy Wotherspoon is arguably the best sprinter of his time, winning four World Sprint Championships (1999, 2000, 2002 and 2003), three distance world titles, and a slew of World Cup victories. In addition, he bettered the world record in the 500 m, 1000 m and sprint combination various times, usually at his home rink, the Calgary Olympic Oval. By contrast, the tall Canadian has not performed well at the Olympic Games. He won a silver medal at his first Olympics in the 500 meter, but failed to reach the podium on the 1000 m. In 2002, as the top favorite in the shortest distance, he fell after just a few strokes. Although eliminated, he did skate the fastest time in the second run. His other three Olympic races, the 1000 m in Salt Lake City and both events in 2006 were similarly disappointing. Following the Torino Games, he took a sabbatical, returning in late 2007 with the Toronto Olympics as his target. Personal Bests: 500 – 34.03 (2008); 1000 – 1:07.03 (2008); 1500 – 1:46.18 (2006); 5000 – 7:37.36 (1996).

name: Keith Brantly
description: Keith Brantly was a distance runner who ran the marathon at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. Brantly attended the University of Florida where he won Southeastern Conference titles in 1983 in the 10K and cross-country. He won a gold medal in the 10K at the 1985 World University Games. Brantly won various US titles, including the 1993 20 km, and in 1995 won the 10K, the 25K and the marathon, repeating as US marathon champion in 1998. He later worked in medical sales, based in Jacksonville, Florida, also serving as a personal running coach and a motivational speaker. Personal Best: Mar – 2-12:31 (1998).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (1–0–0 1985 Kobe ATH gold: 10000 m)

name: Rolf Beilschmidt
description: Rolf Beilschmidt was trained as a tool maker, who later studied Scientific Instrumentation, and since 1991 has been Head of the National Training Center in Thuringia and director of the Olympic Training Base Erfurt. He then became chief executive of the National Sport Association of Thuringia. In 1990 he was the last Vice-President of the Sports Federation of East Germany. He was 1977 East German Athlete of the Year after finishing seventh in the high jump at the 1976 Montréal Olympics, and is married to former 400 m runner Waltraud Kämpf. Beilschmidt won the 1977 World Cup high jump and placed fourth in 1979, winning bronze at the 1978 European Championships, and the 1975 European Cup, winning this competition in 1977 and placing second in 1979. His East German national titles were 1973-78 (indoor) and 1974-79, and 1981 (outdoor). In 1978 he set a European record, recording 2.29 m. Personal Best: HJ – 2.31 (1977).

description: Adopted British nationality on 4 March 2004. Personal Bests: 5000 – 15:22.59 (1999); 10000 – 32:07.44 (2000).

name: Kikuko Inoue
description: Kikuko Inoue was inspired to take up equestrian by Takeichi, Baron Nishi, who had won the individual jumping event at the 1932 Los Angeles Olympics. It would not be until 1964 in Tokyo, however, that she would make her Olympic debut, when she came sixth and last with the Japanese team in dressage, alongside Nagahira Okabe and Yoritsune Matsudaira. Individually she was the squad’s top rider, finishing 16th out of 22 competitors. Nonetheless, this made her the first woman to represent Japan in equestrian and, until 2004, one of only two, with Naoko Sakurai, who competed in 1988. Inoue returned to the Games in 1972 in Munich, where she was 32nd, and, at the age of 63, in 1988 in Seoul, where she was 46th. At the time, this made her the oldest Olympic representative of Japan and, as of 2018, it remains the record for Japanese women.

name: Marianne Zechmeister
description: Marianne, sister of Christa Zechmeister, was a West German alpine skier who participated in the 1980 Lake Placid Winter Games, where she finished ninth in the downhill race. At the Youth Europeans she won a bronze in 1975 and a silver medal in 1977 in the slalom events. Nevertheless, she failed to reach a podium in any World Cup race. She retired from competitive skiing in 1982.
special_notes: Sister of Christa Zechmeister

name: Bernhard Heinemann
description: Bernhard Heinemann was a West German whitewater canoeist who finished 16th in the C-1 at the 1972 München Olympics. The canoe slalom events were held on the Augsburg course for the first time (and for the last time until 1992). Heinemann won a silver medal in 1971 and a gold medal in 1973 at the World Championships in the C-1, and also won with the C-1 team three more golds in 1969, 1971 and 1973.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Wildwater Canoeing World Championships (4–1–0 1969 Bourg St.Maurice gold: C1 team; 1971 Meran gold: C1 team, silver: C1; 1973 Muotathal gold: C1 and C1 team)

name: Rosmarie Bleuer
description: Rosmarie Bleuer made her début at the junior Swiss national championships in 1945, when she took gold in the downhill and came in second in the slalom. The following year, she was junior national champion in both events and, two years later, made her senior international début at the 1948 St. Moritz Olympics. There, she finished sixth in the combined, ninth in the downhill, and thirteenth in the slalom. Her next major stop was the 1950 World Championships, where she was 15th in the downhill, 17th in the giant slalom, and disqualified in the slalom. She came in second in the slalom at the national championships in 1951, behind Olivia Ausoni, but retired from active competition at the end of the season.

name: Ricardo González
description: Ricardo González was one of the top South American basketball players in the late-1940s and early-1950s. The spoils of his 50 appearances for the Argentine national team include a gold medal at the 1950 World Championships, silver at the 1951 and 1955 Pan American Games, and a fourth-place finish at the 1952 Helsinki Olympics. He also competed at the 1948 London Games, where Argentina placed 15th among 23 nations in the tournament. Domestically he spent most of his career, until he was forced to retire in 1956 for political reasons, with Sportivo Palermo, but also won an Argentine Championship with Capital Federal in 1947. In 1980 he was named one of the five best basketball players in Argentina’s history, and in 2009 was made a member of the FIBA Hall of Fame.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–2–0 1951 Buenos Aires BAS silver; 1955 Ciudad de México BAS silver) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Basketball World Cup (1–0–0 1950 ARG gold)

name: Mehtab Singh
description: Mehtab Singh boxed for India as a light-heavyweight at the 1972 München Olympics, losing in the first round. Singh’s biggest international accomplishment was winning a silver medal at the 1974 Asian Games. He was also the 1973 Asian Champion. Singh won international bouts when India faced off against Germany in 1973 and 1974. He was given the Arjuna Award in 1973 for his service to Indian boxing. Singh was honorary captain (retired) of 1 Guard (2 Punab).

Freestyle (7th); 2002 European Championship: 120.0 kg. Freestyle (7th); 1992 European Championship: 90.0 kg. Freestyle (9th); 1995 European Championship: 100.0 kg. Freestyle (9th); 2003 European Championship: 120.0 kg. Freestyle (12th).

name: André Vandekerkhove
description: André Vandekerkhove, better known mononymously by his ring name “Androt”, won the Belgian amateur flyweight and bantamweight boxing titles in 1919, and was the champion in flyweight once again in 1920. Born in the Netherlands, he was one of four boxers from Bruxelles (Brussels) selected to compete at the 1920 Olympic Games held in Antwerpen. There, he was one of two Belgians that competed in the flyweight tournament, alongside Jef Charpentier of Antwerpen, and lost his only match in a decision to Pete Zivic of the United States. Androt began competing as a professional shortly after the Olympics, garnering a record of 11 wins (5 by KO), 16 losses, and 6 draws in a career spanning five years.

name: Einar Eriksson
description: Einar Eriksson had the following podium finishes at major championships: 3rd in the 1953 World Championships Featherweight class (307.5 kg); 3rd in the 1950 European Championships Featherweight class (295.0 kg); 3rd in the 1953 European Championships Featherweight class (307.5 kg).

name: Dave Fairbank
description: David Fairbank swam for Rio Americano High School in California, and competed at the 1972 Olympics while a high school student. Fairbank swam mostly freestyle and butterfly. He played water polo and baskketball in high school in addition to swimming. He also competed for the Arden Hills Swim Club.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Set a World Record in Long Course Swimming (4×100 m freestyle relay – 28 August 1972 - 28 August 1972: 3:28.84 (28 August 1972; München, FRG))

name: Hans-Dieter Pophal
description: Springboard diver Hans-Dieter Pophal, son-in-law of well-known diver Olga Jensch-Jordan, finished eighth at the 1960 Roma Olympics and fourth four years later in Tokyo. He also won East German national titles in 1958, and from 1960-67. In 1962 he won a silver medal at the European Championships. Pophal later worked as a swimming and diving coach. In 1994 he earned two titles at the Senior’s Worlds in Montreal. In 1998 he won three more World Championships in Casablanca, and in 2000 added another one, while in 2003, Pophal claimed three European titles.
special_notes: Son-in-law of Olga Jensch-Jordan Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Aquatics Championships (0–1–0 1962 Leipzig DIV silver: 3 m springboard (competed for East Germany))

name: Yumiko Shige
description: Hailing from the ancient port town of Karatsu, Yumiko Shige formed one of the top boats the in women’s 470 fleet in the early 1990s, together with Danish-Japanese sailor Alicia Kinoshita. While they never clinched a major title, they earned various international medals. Their silver medal in Savannah at the 1996 Olympics was the first ever in Olympic sailing for Japan. At the World Championships, they earned silver in 1992 (both at the 470 Worlds, and the Women’s Worlds), and bronze in 1995. They also claimed victories at the prestigious Kieler Woche in 1992 and 1994-95. After the Sydney Olympics, Shige switched to the Moth, before (unsuccessfully) trying to qualify for a fourth Olympics in the Yngling. Her last major competition were the 2008 Yngling Worlds. She died of breast cancer at the age of 53.

name: Vincenzo Cuccia
description: Vincenzo Cuccia was a member of the Italian sabre team that won the gold medal at the 1924 Olympics. His contribution to the victory was minimal, fencing in only one match and losing 3 of his 4 bouts. He also took home a bronze, from the team épée. Cuccia later became a journalist for Italian sports newspaper Gazzetta dello Sport.

name: Burke Jones
description: Burke Jones played club football with Bridgeville FC, in a small suburb of Pittsburgh. Jones earned three caps in 1924 with the US national team, two at the Olympics. He also played in an exhibition against Poland after the Olympics. Jones was apparently a native of the Pittsburgh area, also dying in Carnegie, Pennsylvania, another suburb of Pittsburgh.

special_notes: Cousin of Duje Bonačić

name: Laura Trott-Kenny
special_notes: Wife of Jason Kenny Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (1–0–0 2014 Glasgow CYC gold: points race) Listed in Olympian Members of the Nobility (Dame)

name: Joe Greene
description: Joe Greene won consecutive bronze medals in the long jump at the 1992 and 1996 Olympics. Greene competed for The Ohio State University, graduating in 1990. He was NCAA Champion in the long jump in 1989, and finished second that year at the NCAA Indoors in the triple jump. He was an eight-time Big 10 Champion in the two horizontal jumps. In addition to his two Olympics, he competed internationally at the 1993 World Championships, but did not make the final, and he won a silver medal in the long jump at the 1993 World Indoor Championships. Greene won his only USA title indoors in 1995 in the long jump. He won a silver at the USA Indoors in 1992 and bronzes in 1991, 1993, and 1996. Greene later went into coaching, working with the jumpers at Ohio State. He was married to German long jumper Susan Tiedtke, although they later divorced, The divorce was another problem that afflicted him after his track career ended. He developed a connective tissue disease and made some bad investments that caused him great financial difficulty. He ended up pawning his Olympic bronze medals to Rick Harrison, owner of the Gold & Silver Pawn Shop featured on the cable television show, “Pawn Stars.” Harrison vowed never to sell them in case Greene ever wanted them back, although eventually he sold them to an Olympic collector, Dr. Marty Urban, who returned the medals to Greene. Greene later re-married and worked as a recruiter in the healthcare industry. Personal Best: LJ – 8.48 [27-10] (1995), 8.66Aw [28-5Aw] (1992).
special_notes: Husband (divorced) of Susen Tiedtke Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Indoor Championships (0–1–1 1993 Toronto silver: long jump; 1997 Paris bronze: long jump)

name: Tom van Dijck
description: Of the sixty international field hockey matches that Tom van Dijck appeared in for the Netherlands, the most important were the five that he played at the 1960 Rome Olympics. In the preliminary round, the Netherlands defeated New Zealand and Denmark, but lost to India and then lost a play-off game against New Zealand, failing to advance. The Netherlands then defeated France and Belgium in the classification round to place ninth overall; van Dijck was absent only for the game against France. He had been selected previously for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, but the Dutch team withdrew from those Games to protest the Soviet Union’s actions in Hungary. Domestically, he played for a time with Sportvereniging Kampong in Utrecht, before moving to Breda after obtaining his dentistry degree, re-joining Breda Hockey Vereniging Push at the age of 40. He later stayed active as a coach and referee with this club.

name: Jimmy Arias
description: Jimmy Arias turned pro in 1980 at age 16, and in 1983, reached a world ranking of #6. He was ranked #5 in the world just before the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics. Arias won five titles in the ATP Tour, and his best Grand Slam finish was in 1983 when he reached the semi-finals of the US Open. His biggest victory was the 1983 Italian Open. Arias did win the 1981 French Open mixed doubles, accompanied by Andrea Jaeger. Arias later became a tennis coach at the University of South Florida. He has also done some television commentary for the Tennis Channel and ESPN International, and in Canada, with the CBC and Rogers Sportsnet.

name: Richard Priestman
description: A bank clerk from Merseyside, Richard Priestman competed for the Liverpool based Nethermoss Club. Whilst his performances in the individual events at his three Olympic Games were unimpressive he excelled as part of the three man British team and won bronze medals at the Seoul and Barcelona Olympics. As his competitive career waned he remained within the sport by working for an archery equipment firm and also as a well-respected coach. He coached England’s junior archers and in 2009 became head coach of the Bangladesh national squad. His Ukrainian born wife, Vladlena (née Kolesnykova) followed her husband as an Olympian and represented Britain at the Sydney Games.
special_notes: Husband of Vladlena Priestman

name: Yevgeny Samsonov
description: Competing for the Krylya Sovetov Moskva eights team that dominated the Soviet and European rowing scene in the mid-1950s, Yevgeny Samsonov won silver at the 1952 Olympics, was the European eights champion from 1953-55, and won the Henley Royal Regatta Grand Challenge Cup in 1954. Domestically he was on Krylya Sovetov eights crew that won Soviet titles in 1949, 1952-54 and 1956. After finishing his sporting career, Samsonov worked as a rowing coach in Moscow, his most famous pupils being the Olympic champions Aleksandr Timoshinin, Anatoly Sass and Gennady Korshikov. From 1959-76, Samsonov was head coach of the Soviet national rowing team and also was the manager of five consecutive Soviet Olympic rowing teams starting in 1960. In 1976 Samsonov was named head of the rowing department at the State Central Order of Lenin Institute of Physical Education (now Russian State University of Physical Education, Sport, Youth and Tourism) and from 1977-81 was the director of Krylatskoye Rowing Canal, where the rowing and canoeing competitions were held during 1980 Olympics. Since 1981 Samsonov has served as an international rowing referee, officiating many international and domestic tournaments.
